body_html:
Tensorflow should behave deterministically. You should be able to tear down the session, clear the default graph, and you're good to go.
…
On Sun, Dec 31, 2017, 8:00 PM Alex Groce ***@***.***> wrote: Thanks. For test reproducibility, how likely do you think it is that starting "fresh" tensorflow tests without a reload will cause nondeterminism (as in, old state not cleared by a reload is corrupt)? I've been running without reload, just added a --noReload to TSTL compile, but if I find bugs, worry it'll make it harder to report good test cases. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body:
Tensorflow should behave deterministically. You should be able to tear down
the session, clear the default graph, and you're good to go.

On Sun, Dec 31, 2017, 8:00 PM Alex Groce <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Thanks. For test reproducibility, how likely do you think it is that
> starting "fresh" tensorflow tests without a reload will cause
> nondeterminism (as in, old state not cleared by a reload is corrupt)? I've
> been running without reload, just added a --noReload to TSTL compile, but
> if I find bugs, worry it'll make it harder to report good test cases.
>
> —
